text: Oh my gosh, the comments.

elements.text: Oh my gosh, the comments.

It’s only easier to learn because that’s how we teach our kids. The first and most basic number is not one. It’s zero.

I am doing my best in teaching my kids this way but the world around has the wrong idea. We’ll see how it goes...

text: Poor kids

text:
In Europe, zero based indexing seems more natural, even outside of programming, as the ground floor is usually 0, the “first floor” is what we in the US would call the second floor, etc.
At least we don’t have programming languages that index like many tall buildings in the US, i.e. 1..12, 14... :joy:

elements.text:
In Europe, zero based indexing seems more natural, even outside of programming, as the ground floor is usually 0, the “first floor” is what we in the US would call the second floor, etc.
At least we don’t have programming languages that index like many tall buildings in the US, i.e. 1..12, 14...

text:
Yes. I’m happy with Julia now, that has the flexibility to handle any base with relative ease (-5..5 if that makes your code cleaner)
Wish other languages weren’t so stuck in their ways!

elements.text:
Yes. I’m happy with Julia now, that has the flexibility to handle any base with relative ease (-5..5 if that makes your code cleaner)
Wish other languages weren’t so stuck in their ways!

text: And kudos to you, Matt, and Tim, for getting things cleaned up and nicely general, not that long after I started with Julia 6 years ago

elements.text: And kudos to you, Matt, and Tim, for getting things cleaned up and nicely general, not that long after I started with Julia 6 years ago

text:
truth is julia does not _always_ generate clean assembly for scalar indexing into tensors, because of 1-based indexing:

<https://gist.github.com/haampie/1d5bf810086b57872f0c1969cafde044>

47 lines for julia vs 26 for C++ w/ clang

elements.text: truth is julia does not
always
generate clean assembly for scalar indexing into tensors, because of 1-based indexing:
47 lines for julia vs 26 for C++ w/ clang

text: OffsetArrays brings it back to 26 though

elements.text: OffsetArrays brings it back to 26 though

text: Do some of these get pulled out of a loop?

elements.text: Do some of these get pulled out of a loop?

text: Yes

elements.text: Yes

text: They're not identical, but the 1-based version actually had shorter asm and was a couple ns faster for me.

elements.text: They're not identical, but the 1-based version actually had shorter asm and was a couple ns faster for me.

text:
The difference can actually be pretty big:
```julia> A = rand(2,2,2,2,2);

julia> @btime cartesian_sum($A)
  40.855 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
16.85355978925075

julia> @btime cartesian_sum_zero($A)
  55.895 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
16.85355978925075```

elements.text: The difference can actually be pretty big:

julia> A = rand(2,2,2,2,2);

julia> @btime cartesian_sum($A)
  40.855 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
16.85355978925075

julia> @btime cartesian_sum_zero($A)
  55.895 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
16.85355978925075

text: I work in a building with 1-based indexing starting two levels below the ground floor. :man-shrugging::skin-tone-2:. I thought the main point was to know how many stairs you have to climb if you come from the street or viceversa.

elements.text: I work in a building with 1-based indexing starting two levels below the ground floor.
. I thought the main point was to know how many stairs you have to climb if you come from the street or viceversa.

text: I never remember. It is P, 1, 2 (G), 3, 4. The lowest level has no number.

elements.text: I never remember. It is P, 1, 2 (G), 3, 4. The lowest level has no number.

text:
When I lived in Brazil as an exchange student, we were in a building that was built on the side of a cliff, there was a parking / car entrance on the bottom floor, then a couple levels of apartments (that only had windows on two sides), then a level that was pillars, the pedestrian entrance, and open large patio area (which was at the ground level for the top of the cliff, and the building address (Rua Florida 211, Salvador, Brazil), plus another (4-5?) floors of apartments above that.
IIRC, it was like that you described, P, 1, 2, G, 3, 4, 5, 6…

elements.text:

IIRC, it was like that you described, P, 1, 2, G, 3, 4, 5, 6…

text: Was going to say half the buildings in hong kong are like that, north entrance on floor 3, south entrance on floor 5… starts to sounds like the star-wars indexing package

text: Pittsburgh too.  It gets real crazy when multiple buildings link together (like on Pitt’s campus).  You can seamlessly walk from Floor 3 to 1 to B2 without going up or down any stairs.
